4.46. a) We call a variety of groups a limit variety if it cannot be defined by finitely many laws, while each of its proper subvarieties has a finite basis of identities. It follows from Zorn’s lemma that every variety that has no finite basis of identities contains a limit subvariety. Give explicitly (by means of identities or by a generating group) at least one limit variety.
A. Yu. Olshanskii
